column4: Reverie Saree in Blush Tulip
column5:
Hand-painted on gossamer-light organza, this piece features delicate violet blooms drifting across a shimmering blush canvas. Each floral motif is finished with a fine gold outline that catches the light with every movement, creating a subtle, ethereal glow.

Because this is a Vâk creation, there is no stencil and no repetition. The curve of each stem and the shading of every petal was decided in the moment by the artisan’s hand—making this saree one of one, belonging only to you.
column24: Apparel & Accessories > Clothing > Traditional & Ceremonial Clothing > Saris & Lehengas
column32: Reverie Saree in Blush Tulip | Hand-Painted Silk Organza | Vâk
column36: For the days when you want to feel as light as you look.
column38: ["Delicate pearl drop earrings or a single diamond string","A messy low bun with a few loose strands framing the face","Strappy nude heels that vanish against your skin","A soft, dewy makeup look with a rose-tinted lip","A small pearl-embroidered potli bag"]
column39: ["A daytime engagement or Roka ceremony in a garden setting","A friend’s baby shower (godh bharai)—festive but soft","An art gallery opening where the dress code is \"effortless\"","A Sunday brunch during wedding season where you want to skip the heavy brocades"]
column40: The artisan treated this fabric less like a garment and more like a watercolor canvas. Using fine-point brushes, the violet pigments were applied in sheer layers to build depth without heaviness. The metallic gold outlining was the final, breathless step—requiring a steady hand and immense patience to ensure the paint sat perfectly on the delicate weave.
column41: This piece is delicate art. Dry clean only—and entrust it to a laundry that understands hand-painted fabrics. Store it rolled in soft muslin to protect the metallic outlines; do not fold it sharply on the painted areas. Avoid spraying perfume directly onto the motifs. Treat it gently, and it will remain a keepsake.

column4: Ember Saree in Rust Gilded Flora
column5:
Hand-painted on sheer, crisp silk organza, this saree holds the warmth of a smoldering fire. The deep rust canvas serves as the backdrop for large-scale floral sketches, rendered entirely in fine metallic gold strokes. The motifs are not filled in; they are outlined with a brush, looking less like a print and more like a line drawing suspended in air.

This is the beauty of Vâk: the artist didn't use a stencil. Every golden curve and stamen was drawn freehand, capturing a flow and spontaneity that a machine can never replicate. It is one of one.
column24: Apparel & Accessories > Clothing > Traditional & Ceremonial Clothing > Saris & Lehengas
column36: For the evening that glows long after the sun goes down.
column38: ["Antique gold jewelry or a statement temple choker to match the metallic brushwork.","A sleeveless blouse with a deep back to play up the sheer drama of the organza.","A bronze-heavy makeup look—glowing skin and eyes, rather than a bold lip.","A sleek, tight bun with gajra to balance the modern sketch-art with tradition.","A metallic box clutch."]
column39: ["A cocktail night or Sangeet where everyone is wearing heavy sequins, and you want to wear art.","Diwali at a friend’s home—the kind of party that starts late and goes until 3 AM.","An evening reception where you want the drama of red without the weight of bridal brocade.","A gallery exhibition or theatre premiere."]
column40: Creating this piece required a steady hand and breathless precision. The artisan treated the organza like a sketchbook, using a fine-tip brush to drag the metallic pigment across the textured weave. There is no room for error with this technique—every line you see was placed with intent, creating a composition that flows organically with the drape.
column41: This piece combines delicate fabric with metallic art. Dry clean only. Inform your cleaner that this is hand-painted handloom. Store it rolled in muslin to prevent the organza from creasing sharply on the painted lines. Iron on low heat on the reverse side only, or steam from a distance. Treat it with the respect you’d give a painting.

column4: Bloom Saree in Sage Chameli
column5:
Hand-painted on sheer organza in the softest sage green. White and yellow chameli flowers scattered across the pallu and body, with dark green leaves that look like they just fell into place. The fabric is light — almost weightless — and the flowers get denser toward the pallu, like a breeze carried them there.

This exact piece is one of one. The way each petal lands, the spacing between the leaves - no other saree will ever look quite like this.
column24: Apparel & Accessories > Clothing > Traditional & Ceremonial Clothing > Saris & Lehengas
column36: For the days when you want to feel like a garden in the morning light.
column38: ["Delicate gold jhumkas or simple pearl drops","Kolhapuris for day, strappy gold flats for evening","Hair in a low bun with a gajra — this saree was made for that","A nude lip and just kohl, nothing more","A sleeveless or spaghetti-strap blouse in matching sage or off-white"]
column39: ["A daytime mehendi where you want to look effortless","Brunch at a destination wedding in Goa or Udaipur","Temple visit followed by lunch at your favorite South Indian place","The kind of kitty party where everyone asks \"where's this from?\""]
column40: This saree was painted over four days on sheer organza — a fabric that doesn't forgive mistakes. The chameli flowers were built petal by petal, white first, then yellow, then the dark leaves last. Each cluster was placed by hand without a stencil, so the pattern feels natural, not manufactured.
column41: Dry clean only — find someone who knows organza. Store flat between layers of muslin, never on a hanger (the sheer fabric stretches). K

column4: Serene Saree in Steel Chrysanthemum
column5:
Hand-painted on sheer organza in a dusty steel blue — the kind of blue that changes depending on the light. White chrysanthemums sit in small clusters across the body and pallu, their petals curling and spinning like they were caught mid-breeze. The flowers are painted in soft white with a slightly raised texture you can feel under your fingers.

This exact piece is one of one. The way each cluster sits, the number of petals on each flower, the spaces in between - no one will ever paint this again.
column24: Apparel & Accessories > Clothing > Traditional & Ceremonial Clothing > Saris & Lehengas
column36: For the woman who walks into a room and brings the calm with her.
column38: ["Your everyday gold chain and small studs — keep it simple","Silver oxidized jhumkas if you want a cooler tone","Kolhapuris for a daytime function, nude pointed heels for evening","Hair in a low bun, nothing fussy","A mauve or berry lip, or just kajal and nothing else","A matching steel blue or ivory sleeveless blouse"]
column39: ["A wedding reception where you want to look composed, not loud","Diwali dinner at your parents' place","Anniversary dinner somewhere with low lighting","An art gallery opening or book launch where you want the saree to do the talking"]
column40: This saree was painted over four days on silk organza. The chrysanthemums were painted freehand - each petal pulled outward from the center in one confident stroke. The clusters were placed across the fabric without any grid or sketch, so they sit the way flowers actually grow - a little uneven, a little wild, but together.
column41: Dry clean only - someone who handles organza and handwork. Store flat or rolled in muslin, never on a hanger. Keep away from direct sunlight. Treat it well and this blue will stay exactly this blue for years.

column4: Bloom Saree in Pistachio Rose Garden
column5:
Hand-painted on sheer organza in the palest pistachio - almost white in some light, green in others. Pink roses sit scattered across the body, each one painted in tight spirals like they're still unfurling. Teal fan-shaped leaves and slender brown branches connect them loosely, the way a garden grows - not in rows, but wherever it feels right. The pallu gathers the motifs together, denser and fuller, like walking deeper into the garden.

This exact piece is one of one. The spiral of each rose, the curve of every branch — this saree will never be painted again.
column24: Apparel & Accessories > Clothing > Traditional & Ceremonial Clothing > Saris & Lehengas
column36: For the woman who carries spring with her, no matter the season.
column38: ["Small kundan studs or gold jhumkas — nothing heavy","Juttis in pink or gold for day, nude block heels for evening","Hair open with a side part, or a loose braid","A pink lip to match the roses, or a soft nude — both work","A sleeveless blouse in matching pistachio or a contrasting hot pink","A small potli bag if you need one"]
column39: ["A daytime haldi or mehendi - you'll look like you belong in a garden","Karva Chauth puja at home","Your sister's baby shower","A festive lunch where you want to look put-together without being overdressed"]
column40: This saree was painted over four days on silk organza. The roses were built from the center out - each spiral painted in a single continuous stroke, which means any wobble would show. The teal leaves were added next, fanning out in curved lines, and the brown branches came last, connecting the motifs into a loose, natural arrangement. No stencil, no sketch - just a steady hand.
column41: Dry clean only - choose someone who handles organza carefully. Store flat or rolled in muslin, not on a hanger. Keep away from direct sunlight. The colors are painted, not printed, so they deserve a little extra care

column4: Bold White Saree in Hibiscus
column5:
Hand-painted on sheer white organza. Large crimson hibiscus flowers - five petals each, painted in a single wash so the red moves from deep to soft within every petal. They sit in clusters on the pallu, cascading like they just fell from somewhere above. Across the body, they're more spaced out - just enough to catch the eye every time you move.

This exact piece is one of one. The size of each bloom, the way the petals overlap, the depth of red in each stroke - no other saree will ever match this.
column24: Apparel & Accessories > Clothing > Traditional & Ceremonial Clothing > Saris & Lehengas
column36: For the days when you don't need to say a word - the saree says it all.
column38: ["Gold statement earrings - chandbalis or polki drops","Red heels if you want to go all in, nude if you want the saree to do the work","Hair in a sleek low bun - keep it clean","A bold red lip, obviously","A sleeveless blouse in white or deep red","A gold clutch or small red potli"]
column39: ["A cocktail reception where you want to be remembered","Karva Chauth — red on white, done differently","New Year's Eve dinner","Your best friend's sangeet when you want to look stunning without competing with the bride"]
column40: This saree was painted over five days on silk organza. Each hibiscus was painted in a single layer of crimson - the petals filled with one confident brushstroke each, no going back. The white gaps between petals are the fabric itself, left unpainted on purpose. The clusters on the pallu were composed freehand, each flower placed to fall naturally into the next.
column41: Dry clean only - someone experienced with organza and pigment work. Store flat in muslin, never folded on the painted areas. Keep away from direct sunlight. The red is vivid now — take care of it and it stays that way.

column4: Serene Saree in Silver Blue Tulip
column5:
Hand-painted on sheer organza in the softest silver blue - the kind that catches light and turns almost lavender in the evening. Small sprigs of blue tulip buds hang from olive-green stems, scattered evenly across the body and pallu. Each bud is painted in two tones - deep navy on one side, sky blue on the other - so they look like they're just about to open.

This exact piece is one of one. The tilt of each stem, the exact shade of every bud — this saree exists only once.
column24: Apparel & Accessories > Clothing > Traditional & Ceremonial Clothing > Saris & Lehengas
column36: For the days when quiet is the loudest thing in the room.
column38: ["Simple gold studs or pearl drops - let the saree stay in focus","Silver jhumkas if you want to lean into the cool tones","Kolhapuris for daytime, silver or nude heels for evening","Hair left open or in a simple low bun","A soft pink lip or just balm and kohl","A sleeveless blouse in matching silver blue or a contrasting navy"]
column39: ["Diwali puja at home followed by dinner","A small engagement or roka ceremony","Office ethnic day when you want to look effortlessly put together","Sunday family lunch where someone will definitely say \"yeh saree kahan se li?\""]
column40: This saree was painted over three days on silk organza. Each tulip sprig was painted stem-first - a single green line, then the leaves, then the buds last. The two-tone blue was done wet - navy laid down first, then sky blue blended in while the paint was still fresh. That's what gives each bud its depth. No two sprigs came out the same, which is the whole point.
column41: Dry clean only - find someone who handles organza well. Store flat or rolled in muslin, not hanging. Keep away from sunlight. The blues are delicate and hand-mixed - they deserve gentle handling.
